question: Question_A_03
sols:
$a$ and $d$ are orthogonal whenever their dot product is equal to zero.
That is,

\begin{align*}
0 = a \cdot d &= \begin{bmatrix}
-3 \\ -3 \\ 3
\end{bmatrix}
\cdot 
\begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ k \\ 2k+1 \end{bmatrix}\\
&= (-3)(-1) + (-3)(k) + (3)(2k+1)\\
&= 3 - 3k + 6k+3\\
&= 6 + 3k\\
&= 3(2 + k).
\end{align*}

Therefore, $\displaystyle k = -2$ is the value for which $a$ and $d$ are
orthogonal.
hints: Two vectors are orthogonal if their dot product is zero.
